sub_topic: Finding the height of objects using trigonometry
message_1: A flagpole casts a shadow of 18 feet when the angle of elevation of the sun is 30 degrees. Find the height of the flagpole.
message_2:
To find the height of the flagpole, we can use the tangent function in trigonometry. The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the side adjacent to the angle. In this case, the angle of elevation is 30 degrees, the shadow (adjacent side) is 18 feet, and we want to find the height of the flagpole (opposite side).

The formula for tangent is:

tan(angle) = opposite side / adjacent side

We can plug in the values we know:

tan(30 degrees) = height of flagpole / 18 feet

To find the height of the flagpole, we can multiply both sides of the equation by 18 feet:

height of flagpole = 18 feet * tan(30 degrees)

Now, we can use a calculator to find the tangent of 30 degrees:

tan(30 degrees) ≈ 0.577

Now, we can multiply this value by 18 feet:

height of flagpole ≈ 18 feet * 0.577 ≈ 10.386 feet

So, the height of the flagpole is approximately 10.39 feet.
